Dear Phil,

I returned from Peru just before the earthquake hit.  After seeing these rural communities, I am wondering how they will survive such event.  Of course, we have heard a lot about what happened in the big cities, but the small towns have the most precarious infrastructure and I expect the biggest losses.

I wanted to report to you now that I have come back and give you some update on what I saw and discussed with my colleagues at PUCP.  As you know, our Sustainable Visions grant deferred our designation of a specific project to pursue until I had visited these communities.  We have now some ideas and my sense is that we want to focus on those that will enable the economic development of these rural communities.

I think I will confer with Burt Swersey and Rob Chernow about these ideas and then proceed to make plans with my colleagues at PUCP.  My hope is that this will be the first of many projects on these communities so that we can have a long-lasting and prosperous relationship with them.

I will keep you posted.


Lupita Montoya, PhD

DESCRIPTION:
What they've done so far:
-set up communication between RPI and Peru
-visited last August. Went to rural village near Cuzco with Ursula.
Saw two needs: water and energy for heating

1-small room to house guinea pigs (energy efficient). Noticed kids with runny noses and respiratory disease. Guinea pigs now live in kitchens and also there is pollution with dung stoves.

2-dairy cooperative. Need for clean water and some energy. Help them produce more and move towards certification. Want income generating project for clean water.  Ursula is getting more information on this.

3- air quality problem. 

-got funding from Mondialago to build a demonstration house (for people) designed by RPI, someone willing to donate land

Some of the original ideas not relevant...this is what the people need.
PW: where's the technology?
Lupita - I'm not a business person - need to talk to Rob Chernow.

Want them to become more self-sustaining. 
Outcome: model that people can implement in their own home. Demonstration project but also someone to provide credit and someone who is going to manufacture this...

PW: get a better understanding re what the approach for dissemination, regardless of what project they choose. What's the economic model 

Thought they were going to pick a project that Grupo was supporting, improve it, work with NESST or others to disseminate ...so they are starting at a much earlier stage. 

What's the economic pressure that's going to drive people to want/buy this? (Those with demonstration projects have stuff but their neighbors don't have it).

Ultimately, their end goal is similar to NCIIA - income generation, locally owned enterprises.
Don't want to dictate the technological innovation, we don't know anything about guinea pigs. General objective - ag productivity.

NCIIA wants to understand economic sustainability. Who's the partner?

Next steps: come to workshop, set up call with Rob Chernow and Phil. Select projects. Focus on economic sustainability. 

Second goal is to institutionalize / making change at RPI - making progress there. Need to decide which kids to come down to Peru next summer.

DESCRIPTION:
UPDATE from Tom's summer trip to Kenya: Tom traveled to Kenya to check on the low cost entrepreneurial efforts. Demonstration sites of appropriate technology. Training and entrepreneurial activities, almost like an incubator. Bringing in training resources. People are hungry to provide skills to students.
Downside - lack of accountabiiity from foreign partners/2 universities (U of Moi and U of Nairobi) have designed water well utility rig and rock crusher - designed but not built. Faculty and students had been killed and fled/delay. 
Don't really know how to motivate them -U of Nairobi hasn't even requested the funds to build a prototype. Lots of excuses, blamed the students. Not a team approach: faculty assigns students. Students did presentations on the work that they've done and they will start construction next semester. (May be British system). Met with Alan Spivey from Kickstart - it costs $14k to drill a well, right now everything is done by hand and the water is impaired. Alan said low cost low powered drilling system would be most beneficial thing to focus on (but how do you get through igneious rock with a low powered engine?) as well as a plow and a cart to carry it arround. Sisal decorticator is limited to Eastern side of the country and there are accessible mills. Tom said that maybe it wasn't the farmers they should have talked to...entrepreneurs will buy the well digger, not the farmers. They (Alan who is in charge of product development) seemed interested in partnering with Penn State as a low cost research arm... Martin and others seem to only want to work with Stanford and IDEO. Tom is open to Alan's offer as a first step since real life problems are everything and Tom feels like he needs to prove himself/provide value. Overall, not on track re where he expected to be, but there is some traction - he stressed deadlines and met a third university. Flow of $, academic calendars are a factor. 
A third university JomoKenyatta has a base power unit developed - could be a stronger partner. Younger faculty with entrepreneurial spirit. By December, waterwell drilling rig, rock crusher, plow and cart will be constructed then field tested. Beyond that, much relies on Kickstart and the partnership that may develop  - if the product is good, they would spend their marketing, distribution and sales forces to promote the product. Tom feels like all the eggs would be in one basket. U of Nairobi could fabricate and market and sell. Would like to see jobs created (but Kickstart outsources to China!!)

he was IR two E-T proposals 5742 and 5743-08. His reaction: Dear Jennifer:

I am at the Academy of Management - I gave a presentation based on some of the work I was able to accomplish through the generousity of NCIIA. I am of course disappointed that NCIIA and I have not found a way to continue our collaboration. I am indeed a bit perplexed - my work seems to exemplify the type of thing NCIIA symbolizes. I have taken an idea, created a working prototype - and built it in the underserved community, I have created a potential business model and I have networked extensively - all the while including students in the processes. I am really not sure why I have not been able to get more funding to finish what NCIIA has allowed me to start. 

As a junior faculty member it is very difficult to find the funds and the time to do this kind of innovation - it seems an odd waste of resources to deny resources for a project that has moved so quickly and yeilded results for the students involved, the community members involved and in addressing a critical waste/resource issue. I am certain that I will find other funders, but I am disheartened by the waste of time and effort that this will require. My biggest issue is that I have so little time - the funds bought me time that has yeilded advances that have been waiting for years to burst forth. I have ten other ideas that are just waiting for the time and resources to enact - now I am back to waiting for funds. This is tragic. 

I have enjoyed working with you. Please let me know what I need to do to conclude my work with NCIIA.

Best, David

DESCRIPTION:
Phone call w/ Phil, Robyn, and Bernard on 9/5/08 regarding the new direction of the grant: Bernard noted that the last payment was received at the end of June, and they'd like to request an extension. They have $21,500 left.
Progress thus far:
Bernard shared that he faced a lot of corruption when trying to complete goals of original proposal. 
Held a workshop on solar energy, 25 students attended (young entrepreneurs, some affiliated w/ university, others not).  Creation of a "green" carpets initiative: grad student researched how carpets are made, and how to create them using green methods.  Wrote master's thesis on this, they will send to us. 
New Idea: There is no wood in Afghanistan for carpeting, and for people in general for heating.  Technology Bernard came across, that involves mixing sawdust and paper, compressed, to create Briquettes to provide cooking and heating fuel. 5 briquettes can provide fuel for a family of 5 for one day. 
They have started a business in Kabul to make the briquettes (employing children who were in prostitution rings) and 5 handicapped young men. They are producing about 1000 briquettes a day, they want to expand this to a bigger business to employ more like 5000 children.  Plenty of material to create the briquettes, they have bakeries interested in using them, which would reduce the cost of bread by 40%
They also want to educate the children who work in the factory - make briquettes in AM, in PM learn up to 5th grade (2-3 hrs per day). 
They proposed using remaining funds to to build a classroom, market the briquettes, and pay teachers.  This new project could benefit local people, 
carpet industry, bread industry, potters. They have also has received a grant from a private donor to work on this project.

Phil's response: different use of funds, but still fits w/ the grant guidelines - would be helpful for us to have more real time notice of how things had changed for them.  Need to hear about dramatic changes earlier on. 
But, new work is exciting - agrees to use of remainder of the funds, but guidelines wouldn't support paying a teacher - what makes sense w/ program guidelines would be to use funds for furthering the development and scaling of the business.  

NEXT STEPS: Phil asked for an update on what was described verbally in writing, and a brief rationale of why briquettes.  They will formally request the extension, as well as create a general work plan and a proposed budget for the project. Bernard said he'd send this the week of 9/8/08. l
on the project. 

Phil also mentioned the new initiative (DR 100) we're going to launch this fall - looking a developing a network of faculty innovators who are working on addressing issues of poverty in the developing world - want to support the expansion of activities - core gp of people are assembling, to help us think about how to do this and what kind of issues/constraints. 100 schools involved in doing curricular work in which students are engaged on and learning about the process of engaging ways to help people out of poverty. Bernard is very interested, and also felt the National Academy of Engineering could be interested - he'd like to connect Phil with NAE to discuss. 
NEXT STEPS: Phil will send some background info next week on this project - Bernard will think about the best way to approach NAE.

Sorry for the delay in responding.  I wanted to receive comment from the various parties involved in Kenya before writing.  The current status regarding university participation on the ag. utility project is as follows:
 
1.  University of Nairobi - the Briggs and Stratton engine was received with much fanfare in January, and that was about all that UoN has undertaken.  They have not even requested access to their $15k subcontract for the construction of the base power unit, nor for the agreed upon attachments.  This relationship has been the basis for our work in Kenya to date.  A faculty member, Madara Ogot, was here at Penn State and a native of Kenya.  He had/has extensive contacts throughout Kenya.  I believe I mentioned, two Decembers ago, with one day's notice, he departed to be employed by UoN's technology-transfer/business development arm - and no one has heard from him since! Thanks Jennifer!

DESCRIPTION:
Spoke to Dara O'Rourke (PI)  for 45 min - he is very humble and wants to make sure we know this startup success is not about $ or personal gain. He can't come to our conference this year but he's agreed to come next year and tell his story (we need to book him early).

Spring 2006 we funded the SV grant  - he had raised some other grant $, hired a programmer, built barcode scanning tools. Worked on rating products, built a team on campus - health scientists, social scientists. Built a couple of prototypes - take a picture of a barcode and send it to your phone while you're in the store. 

Built it to work on Nokia phone (largest seller of handsets in the world). Then went to meet with Nokia and cell phone carriers - they are mini monopolies. Cingular (now merged with ATT) said we'd love to get this tool on our phones but he had to apply to their program and wait 18-24 months to get approval. Will be irrelevant in 2 years! Total nightmare. He felt blocked by carriers.

Then the world changed...
This world has now busted open due to google and apple - allowing apps. Dara realized he needed to develop a free app on itunes and use it on iphone. Don't need permission from cell phone companies. Google has done the same for G1 Android phone.
So refocused on building for iphone and android. Even though it's smaller #, it's the way to go.

Got other small grants and went back to the funders but they didn't want this to be a small Berkeley research project. Wanted it to be out in the world and influencing the market. (The Funders Network for Sustainable Production and Consumption - affinity group run out of Environmental Grantmakers in NY) said we love it so much we don't want to fund you anymore. Get it off campus and make it a stand alone company.  Wanted it to become sustainable.

Funders Network introduced him to cleantech / social venture space/people in Bay area. 
Dara  "I'm not a business guy - I want to give it away for free."

Fall 2007 spun it off campus - raised $ from social angel investors - licensed some of the IP (had filed a patent). Created a For benefit  (B Corporation) corporate company. Incorporated in NY state, which allows you to become a for benefit (not possible in CA or DE) - clear triple bottom line in articles of corporation - shall consider all the stakeholders (not just maximizing shareholder return).

Talked to a lawyer in Palo Alto to set this up. Created legal structures and mission and then went out to raise more $ from venture investors. Raised $3.6M total.  which has allowed them to hire F/T staff, including ebay and yahoo staff and scientists.  (Amazing that they invested when Dara hasn't figured out how to make $ yet).

44k from us, $150k from other foundations (spent all on grad students) to build the proof of concept.

Still early, don't want to claim success. gone from on campus experiment to a startup.

Feedback has been great - this should exist. We want to know this information. Other feedback: Too much like a database, can you make it simpler. I've got 15 seconds to decide what cereal to buy with a screaming toddler in the supermarket. 

Have divided the world into 3 spaces:

HEALTH - personal health and wellness - by far the #1 concern - household chemicals, shampoo, food, toys, things you put on your kids. This is easiest to assess/ scientific ingredients/carcinogens. 
ENVIRONMENTAL - pretty good metrics exist.
SOCIAL- most qualitative and debatable. Personal ethics. Trying to make a personalization tool  - do you care about animal testing, how a company treats its workers? Some don't care about labor rights. Enable a vegan filter for example - you will never see a product with animal testing. 

So far about 100,000 on mobile apps and 700k on the website have tested this so far - giving them great feedback. Several hundred thousand users per month, goal is millions.

Not sure how they will make $. Want to give it away for free. Would need to be something on the backend. Several cities have asked to license it so they can buy green. Institutional buyers are pressured to buy green - one possible revenue source. Everyone is going to Dara asking for data. Free to users but $ charge institutions? 

Goal - 10 seconds or less - everything they need to know about the product.

Every week there's a new scandal - poisonous meat, toys, product, salmonella etc. which is like free marketing for goodguide.

Thinks being in CA has made a huge difference. Not sure how economy will affect them but feels lucky they got investment when they did.

Two of his engineers went to work for goodguide  - didn't want people to drop out of school for this! Some are now back working on their phds, some interns, some students still involved. Everyone has equity in the company - even the dataprocessing person - went beyond B corp rules. 

Will get a student to write up a final report and will keep me posted via email of progress. jkj

Here's an excerpt from the interview where GoodGuide is mentioned (See attached link for whole video):

---
DANIEL GOLEMAN: Well, Bill, I think there are two things that are new. One is that life cycle assessment goes way beyond carbon footprint at any given point. For example, a glass bottle, a glass jar, they analyze that, its manufacturing, to 1,959 discreet steps.

At every step of the way there are myriad impacts on the environment, on health, on the people involved, and so on. So, first, we have a vaster sense, and a much more accurate sense, of really what the impact is. And the second thing is, and this is the big breakthrough, that information is now available to you and me while we're shopping. So that we can use it to make better decisions.

BILL MOYERS: How so?

DANIEL GOLEMAN: Well, there's a fabulous website. It's called GoodGuide. GoodGuide.com. And it summarizes, it draws on about 200 of these databases, and summarizes for us in, you know, ten points — ten is the best, one is the worst — how this product stacks up on its environmental health and social impacts compared to other products of its kind. What this does, Bill, is give us what's called radical transparency. Suddenly, you know, we've all vaguely known, things have carbon fingerprints. Now we can know exactly which is better.

On Jun 9, 2010, at 2:48 PM, Thomas Colledge wrote:

Hello Jennifer:

I hope you are doing well.  It has been a long couple months for me as my father had his second knee replacement in March – which was followed by a whole series of complications.  The most recent complication was a fall on his bad knee just last week which resulted in chest pains, etc.  and another hospital visit.  And so it goes.

I wanted to write to provide you with an update on the status of the Agricultural Utilities System project – which evolved into the water well drilling project.  The summary follows:

As you will recall, the objectives for spring semester 2010 were as follows:

a. redesign, construct and test the engine/power train to reduce costs and increase portability

b. redesign, construct and test the drilling rig to permit easier removal of debris as well as the addition of enhanced safety features – with testing to be accomplished specifically on ‘hard’ Kenyan igneous rock.

c.  complete the business plan for the water well drilling fabrication business.

This past semester (Spring 2010) saw the third iteration of the engine/power train successfully completed along with the development of the full business plan for the effort.  These were undertaken in collaboration with the JKUAT students and faculty with field surveys completed.  Thus, two of the goals listed above have been completed.  Unfortunately, the re-design, construction and testing of the drilling rig apparatus as proposed by the JKUAT students/faculty was not undertaken.  Recall that this part of the system was designed, constructed and tested on ‘soft’ rock at Penn State over the past couple years. It is operational.  However, the goal for this past semester was to have the JKUAT students construct the drilling rig apparatus in Kenya to enable testing on the ‘hard’ igneous rock there.  Attempting to move forward on this with JKUAT has been less of a struggle when compared with the University of Nairobi and Moi University – but still a struggle.  JKUAT closed its campus a month early – ending at the end of March for unknown reasons.  They were not able to construct the drilling rig system and associated power train system. Dear Jennifer,
Greetings from Hope College!  I just came across the attached photos while browsing facebook and thought they would be worth sharing with you.  As you may recall, the Sustainable Visions Grant that we were awarded by NCIIA back in the spring of 2007 was directed towards community-based training for household water filtration.  At that time, our in-country NGO counterpart, Life and Water Development Group - Cameroon (LWDG-C), was just getting established and our joint project in Nkuv, Cameroon, was their very first experience addressing water and sanitation issues.  Our primary intention throughout the grant period was to focus on training members of a very rural farming community on the ins and outs of household water filtration using an established technology (the Manz Biosand Filter).  LWDG-C was responsible for facilitating this process, but we later came to realize that their role as leaders and entrepreneurs was going to be the key ingredient if our efforts were ever going to extend beyond this one farming community.  I am very happy to report that, seven years after we first began working with LWDG-C, this group has gone on to have a very significant impact in communities all across the country.  Their most recent work has involved partnering with Guiness of Cameroon to organize and implement community scale water projects.  The attached photos give you a sense of the scale of this collaboration.  The sustainable vision grant from NCIIA played a huge part in supporting our initial efforts in Nkuv, but it also helped us to orient our program towards one of training and empowerment as opposed to delivery and aid.  I just thought it might be helpful for you and those who sponsor your efforts to see evidence that investments you are making in people and programs do (eventually) bear fruit.

Kind regards,
Jeff

DESCRIPTION:
Eric met with Dara at UC Berkeley: Met with Dara O’Rourke of Goodguide.
They have spun out a Business: Business operation called “Premier" which is the for-profit side of the company now. They basically get large store chains to choose products they will put on the shelf using Goodguide rating algorithm. So far working with Target, CVS and next week Walmart. They are leveraging the buying power of these chains to influence consumer behavior (if bad stuff isn't available, people cant buy it). This project is supported by UL (the stamp on your toaster) which is a consumer safety company trying to update its rating system. Dara continues teaching, being CEO, etc.
Goodguide never became profitable - none of the typical online business models (subscriptions, pay as you go, etc.) worked. They also couldn't be valid and take $$ from corporations they were rating, etc. So they are a nonprofit serving the public good.
Discussed the proposed rubric for E-Teams.  He said this is “complicated” and will only have people trying to improve their mousetrap. He suggests a process that has student teams thinking much more deeply and broadly about product design (e.g. instead of eliminating a toxic rain repellent for your jacket, use entirely different material that repels water). This could be a powerful part of training but is not a “simple checklist”  He also noted that giving people info about what to avoid is easy part - revolutionizing their ideas is tough. That said, we should SERIOUSLY rethink the idea of this rubric or tool so we don't inadvertently add to the problems. We are always encouraging our teams to “catch mice” not invent better mousetraps.
Discussed alumni network (what he would like, what he needs, etc.).  Dara indicated he’s never thought of himself as an NCIIA alumni, but clearly he is. He said it would be great to connect with other alum, but in a meaningful way.  For example, a retreat would be of no value unless we gave value (an opportunity to think strategically about the next three years of his business). There are “literally dozens” of e-ship events every day in SF and Silicon Valley… who has the time?!  That said, he does want to give back and feels he has important lessons to share.  (he’d be a great mentor) and is committed to continuing his work at Berkeley and writing on his experiences.
He’s super articulate, super interesting story - he might be a GREAT speaker for Sustainability Award…
